Home, Nov 13, 1882
My dear Sister,
I thought I would 
write my first letter to you, as 
you have been so faithful in writing 
while I was sick. We have been 
home since Friday, as I believe 
Jennie wrote you. Came just 
in time, as it was an unusually 
warm and lovely day ‑ and it has 
rained some every day since. Today 
or this P.M. it is snowing quite 
hard. Esther and little Frankie 
are with us yet, and are a great 
deal of company. Our girl, Sadie 
Parry, came today, a little girl 
about 13 or so I should think. I 
am gaining quite nicely I 
think — if I do not have another 
spell, think I shall get along.

written sideways across top of page look for one pretty often when I go down to N.Y. I wonder how tall Gracie is now & whether she has quite forgotten us. When have you seen Mrs. J Thomas —my love to her also Mrs. Winston We will bring some of the unclear with us — Shall I send one or two copies by mail?  Much love — I hope you will not stop writing now A. is a little better I have a letter near finished for J.E. Saturday and I must add a little to it

I am still quite weak, and do 
not try to sit up very long at a 
time — feel quite miserably in 
the morning, and so play lazy 
then, and do not get dressed 
till 9 or 10 o'clock. My head 
still pains me a good deal at 
times, especially when I get tired [symbol: upward carat] with throbbing and dizziness sometimes 
I am in hopes that it will be 
better as I get stronger. Have 
been taking China & Acon — think 
it helps me. Have been feeling 
quite smart today, and walking 
about the house a good deal, 
but do not try to do [underlined] any thing 
hardly yet. Yesterday I did not 
feel so strong.
Robbie began his school today 
so we will not be likely to send 
with him to the village quite 
so often as before. If he goes down 
tonight he has promised to let us 
know that we may send this with

him — It was quite a disappointment 
for me not to be able to go down today 
but the roads must be very muddy. 
We are very thankful that Anna 
is gaining. We try not to worry about 
what we shall do next year or even 
this winter. It is a great relief to 
have some help. It will make it 
so much easier for us to get ready 
to leave — if indeed we do get away 
from here this winter. Yesterday 
Ellen Davies and her husband were 
here also Mr. and Mrs. Prichard 
— they took dinner with us and 
made quite a little stay — the rain 
began just as we were ready to sit 
to the table and that kept them 
a little longer with us. Mrs. Jones, 
Cobin, and Lizzie Davies also called 
on their way from church, and 
Mr. & Mrs. G. Griffith — so you see 
we are not neglected.
We had a splendid long letter

from John Eddie, Saturday. He 
enjoys himself there — tho' he says 
every time that if we say so he 
will come right home. We think 
as we are not staying here this win-
ter he had better remain with his 
father till we come back here. 
He is a member of the Literary 
Society and had just been elected 
President — an office which con=
tinues one month. His father's ^ health is 
about as usual, his shoulder no better! 
Do you think it is rheumatism?
Robbie has a little molatto boy work-
ing for him —a kind bright, active 
boy. He reads a little and I have 
promised to look up a book for him. 
I will give him a testament and 
perhaps I can find something else 
that he can read. — I have not had 
time to look much. — Give much love 
to Mrs. Jones — I am glad she boards with 
David — tell Mary and Gracie they may

[sideways across the top] ought to be with Edward some are on account of the books. — I believe this cold snap has taken my courage someway and you must make allowances. Please write often. Sometimes I wish all New Yorkers were well — I am thankful they do not keep you so busy that you could find no time to write. Accept much love from both of us — your sister Jennie Everett
Home, Remsen, Nov. 14 '82
My dear Sister,
Yours of the 11th was received by us this morning and we thank you so much for your faithfulness in writing — your letters coming so often now cheer us and keep us company! and the cards and other pretty things are duly appreciated — we enjoy them ourselves, and they help us entertain our company! The cat that you sent in the time table is just lovely — so is the head you sent in the letter — we had no cat! Wonder if the mice will fear this one! —
We had quite a fall of snow yesterday and the night was raw and cold. The cows have been in all day today the first time this season

as it has been freezing all day and the snow covers the ground. Sadie Perry, a little girl of about 12 or 13, came yesterday P.M. just before the rain changed to snow. We hope she will be contented to stay while we need her help and company. Her parents live in Jim Powell's new house — and they have quite a large family nine in all. The baby was Sadie's especial charge and she misses her most. She never has lived out before. Jane Esther and Frankie helped us put up the coal stove in the sitting room this morning — as Esther said it would be so much better for Anna and we find it very comfortable indeed — it is the stove we had in the parlor last winter. We also burn coal in the cook stove in the kitchen, so we keep the house warm. G. G. came for Esther & Frankie very soon after we had finished with the

stove and took them away before dinner. It seems more lonely without them. Frankie was so full of life — she kept skipping in to the bedroom to tell Anna what progress we were making and just what we were doing. This made the time not seem nearly so long, tho' poor child it was 11 a.m. before she was dressed and at dinner time she said it seemed as tho' she could not get warm anywhere — but when I opened the oven doors, she changed her tune! It is nicely warm now even in the bedroom. A. has been writing three pages of a letter to Mate this evening and gives me [[underlined][one]] page to fill! She is resting now on the sofa. May Ann brought little Lewis over this afternoon to visit us, and after awhile Libbie came too and we had a pleasant time with them. Mary Ann and Ikie have gone to the village tonight so we hope they will find something for us in the post office — I was sorry not to have had this letter ready to send. Anna

keeps on with the acon and china — she takes them in water. She has not taken any of Dr Wiggins pills since coming home — her bowels troubled her and so she stopped and as you say the acon and china act on the liver, I think she trusts to them. It is a week today since she had the last attack of nose bleed — We hope she will have no more. Her head troubles her a good deal all the time and she does not gain her strength very fast. He lies down much of the time — We hope the cold weather has not come to stay and that she will get strong enough to make you the proposed visit. — We are very glad to know you have heard from Edward as it is our first news from him since he reached Iowa City — two weeks or a little less ago. I must write to La Crosse — hoping to send to Remsen tomorrow. We had a pleasant time in Glyn, but not just as you imagine. Anna was very feeble and Mrs. P. quite timid about my leaving her lest she might have an attack while I was gone. So I did not have much running around — yet they were all very, very kind to us and we hardly know how to repay them. They would not make any bill! Neither would Jane Esther — She was here from Friday to Tuesday and Frankie too! Perhaps you can help us think of something — You ought to see baby's likeness. He is laughing and it is just splendid = Carroll’s? and Charlie's are good too, but not quite so good. Write to Mate that she may not forget you while she has some left! Ellen Davies came in just as we were going to sit to dinner. She had just eaten at Robbie's so would not partake with us. It is sunny today and thaws a little now at noon. You say nothing about having us make you a visit this fall. Would it be a great disappointment if we do not go this fall? My dear Sister 
It has been about 
four days since we have had any 
mail, or sent any letters off - it 
seems a long time I assure you, 
but we live in hopes that there 
will be a rich feast for us when there 
is a chance to get it from the 
Post office.  It has been storming 
very hard since yesterday morning, 
and I suppose we are now quite 
effectually "stormed in."  We do not 
worry, however, as we have good 
fires, (three of them part of the time) 
and keep very comfortable.  Robbie 
will be out of school tomorrow, so 
I thought I would write, hoping that 
something will call him to the 
village, and we can send this by him.
our letters by him
and get some oil. 
I am quite well
and we try to 
keep cheery 
tho we feel 
that we ought 
to get away from 
here as soon 
as possible.
We are quite 
warm and 
comfortable so 
far. Love 
J & A R E 
write often

We were reading over some of your 
letters last evening, received when 
Jennie was in Turin, and some 
of them she had not taken time to 
read before, or perhaps I had not 
given them to her. I am sorry 
you are so anxious (underlined) about us, 
and fear that you think me worse 
off than I really am. I do not 
think I feel as strong as usual this 
very stormy weather, but on the whole 
think I am gaining strength about 
as fast as we could expect. My appe-
tite is quite good, and I usually sleep 
pretty well.  I think we will arrange 
to go from home as soon as possible 
now, but cannot tell yet when that 
will be. We have not seen Mr. P. 
since thanksgiving day, and as he 
then spoke of coming here to stay 
this winter, we want to see or hear 
from them before we go.  I suppose 
the stormy weather has kept them

away. Edward has a good many acounts that we ought to look and I don't know but one ought to go to Surmin night away and have these settled, as it would seem better to attend to their Dover. One advantage of this would be that we need not hurry, but could take them slowly and to not get over tired. This would change our felan aberel visiting you soon, but how would it do for us to come to N. B. Howard Merry when the roads well be healthy if in this part of the country! If we should go there wore, we would not feel as if we could play as long as lerhafs we might after the accounts have been settled. E. went home last Monday eve. He came on the Saturday evening Train which was run off the track soon after ;leaving Utiea  making it

four hours later than usual on reaching Remsen, - E. staid at J.D. Griffith's that night, as David came on the same train and it was very stormy- came up here Sunday morning, quite unexpected to us. We had a very nice visit with him Sunday- Monday he wrote letters, and had some other writing to do- so we could not visit so much. We are very glad he is at home before this heavy storm. I wonder if this storm reaches you- it is something very unusual for us at this time of the year, as you know our storms generally come in Feb. and March. -I cannot think fast enough to write what I want. Robbie has just come to say he is going to the village- so we will send

At Ellen Davies' Tuesday
Dec. 26, 1882
My dear Sister, I brought a pencil and paper that I might send you the check- I send both of them in this- The smaller one for you to use for Christmas (underlined) for yourself or anyone and us, just as you like- We were down at Jane's last evening to a goose supper and today we have come here for a duck dinner (underlined).  Anna is much better since the weather is so mild- tho' she finds it takes about all her strength to come out two days in succession! It is so pleasant- and we had promised Ellen we would come if we could. Anna walked over to Robbie's Sunday before
[Top left corner, vertical writing:]
Mate's thumb continue's quite sore. There are several cases of whooping cough about and they are ??? lest Robbie may have it. He has a little cough now- Ellen wants me to tell you- She is going to New York soon and will see you- David Price is there now with Nancy spending holidays - J.E.

last- and as they chanced to come all from Jane's also we stayed to tea- That was the only out Anna had had since cousin Mary was here before Thanksgiving- I fear I have been too indifferent about getting A. out- it does her so much good. There was no one down to Jane's last evening but Robbie's folks and us- a family gathering- very pleasant and quiet.- R. came over with the sleigh and two horses and we rode with them- Owen had sent them all some presents and Jane had been to Utica lately and bought some, so that we had lots of pretty things to see- R's family had all been over to Libbie's Mother's in the day time and he brought us your cards from the mail - and Jane gave us each one more - so we too had our presents- I wish you could have been there with us- The supper

was nice - the goose so tender and sweet &a&c??.  Anna rested quite well last night especially the first part - she does not normally rest so well towards morning.  There is to be no company with us today here except a daughter of Mr. Davies & here little girl- they have not come yet. As we were coming David Griffith brought us the mail - a letter from Edward and one from John Eddie - J.E. almost started home right after he got my last letter - I told him about the snow and he felt that he ought not to leave us so alone, especially as E. wrote that Anna was worse - but thinking it over he concluded to wait as there would not be much more need of his help now the time is so near for Mr. P to come and we go to Eddie's- I must write to him- I am afraid I was a little down when I wrote and he, poo boy, must have brighter news next time. We are getting

along nicely now - Jane Esther was 
with us three days last week and 
she has promised to come one day 
this - David Griffith comes tomorrow 
- we think we will be pretty 
well through so that Mr P's folks will 
find it comfortable to move in.  They 
are going to put their coal store in 
place of our coal store and we will 
have our carpet taken up to make room 
for theirs.  Anna stands it better 
than I thought she could.  We do not 
move things much up stairs.
If you send us anything by express 
any time remember the studants lamp 
we miss it good deal evenings and we are 
taking to Turin what we have of it.
We do not know just when we 
will go - probably we will stay a 
few days to seal after they come.  
Write often and let us keep each 
other cheery thus.  Much love to you 
and J.H.B.  I must write to J.E.

Friday Dec 30/82
Your cheery two letters 
were received last evening 
- we had not heard in 
some time, so were 
very glad to get them.  We 
expect Mr P here Monday 
- we will probably stay 
a few days after to get 
rested, but not long. 
Will write again soon. 
- Much love - 
Mr P has asthma 
today and could not 
come - so our coal 
store will remain 
probably till Monday. 
Dr Griffith will come 
and help us that day - 
was here today & one day before

M.H. Everett, M.D.
433 W 34th St
New York

Remsen Jan 11, 1883
Dear Sister,
It does not much look like our going away just now. It has been very cold all the week and they they [crossed out] did not publichs meeting tonight on that account. Anna does not get over her cold very fast. She has not ventured to go to any of the meetings this week and I have been but once. We are quite comfortable here at home. Mr. & Mrs. P. are going to the village this a.m. to spend the day I think - he went to Glyn yesterday- Did I tell you Maggie talks of making Owen a visit and calling on you by the way. Have you seen Jennie Twombly lately - give my love to her when you do. Wonder what is to be done about about the class letter! I think I must join the Alumni Association - How is your health & business? Is Mrs.
[Top left corner, vertical writing, cont from bottom of page]
J. as well as usual? Do you go to the Welsh? Ch sometimes? When is there Tea Party? How are they at J.'s? love to Suzz & her mother - Have you had any bananas lately? How are oranges? This will change?--

M. H. Everett M. D.
433 W 34th St 
New York

Remsen Jan 19,"83
Dear Sister, 
We received yours with the tintype. You do not look very well - wish you might have a little rest and taste of the country. Mr & Mrs. P. are going to Prospect today & we send this with them. It is mild and pleasant- we can have our windows open for a little time quite often. Anna does not get over her cold- has rather added to it. She was poorly during the other storm and now this one is over we hope she will be better- She stayed alone while we went to church and very few were there- Mr. Hughes preached however- We do not know when we shall go to Turn - we are comfortable here - sit in the room with Mr. & Mrs. P. often for a changed and we make fire in the back kitchen once in a while- We have had no mail since Friday a.m. - 
[top left corner, continued from bottom of page]
Write often as you can Much love to John R. and to Jane How are they at Hillsdale? Cousin Fannie writes that Ellen has been sick but was better when she wrote Shall we send ??? to Mrs Winston?

M. H. Everett M. D. 
433 W 34th St
New York

Turin, Feb. 9, 1883.
Dear Sister, You have doubtless had Edward's postal and know that we came her Tuesday last safely and comfortably. I have been trying to write you a letter but have been rather tired and indolent. I had a hard cold several days before starting with lame shoulders and I suppose that made me feel less energetic. It was well that we came Tuesday as it has not been so pleasant since. Yesterday and today have been blustering days - Edward is home this p.m. attending to our business with Anna Wednesday evening he and Mate went with George to the golden wedding of a cousin- Mr. Emory Allen who lives near Constableville-
[top left, vertical writing:]
We had a letter from J.E. as we came Tuesday- He thinks he ought to come home in May or early in June- have not answered yet- Will have to do so soon. He will be glad to get to his studies once more and we hope the past year has not been without good. Robert has just waked and is now sitting in his high chair eating an apple- He can walk almost alone - quite alone for a few steps- He will let go of your hand and raise his up? so cunningly when "all alone" as he stands on the floor.

Turin, Feb. 17, 1883
Dear Sister, 
We hope you had a nice visit with Maggie. Clara comes in now and then to see us and we enjoy having her do so. We have not been to call on her yet as you know I have had such a time with my shoulder and arm. It is better now tho' still aching with the least exposure to cold. I went to church yesterday afternoon- tho' it hurt my arm every step I took on the icy walk- and in church it ached a good part of the time. Still I think it did me no harm to go. Today Mate washed and I rubbed out our things. I went to rest afterwards and had a good sleep, - hence this letter! I have not
[top left corner, vertical writing:]
hurt him. Robert is about the nicest baby we ever saw. Wish you might see him too. We are sorry Gracie is sick but hope she is better now - Give our love to Mrs. J. and Mary and a kiss to Gracie. I wonder if she still remembers us. Remember us to Mrs. Akin? and her dear little ones - also to Mrs. Thomas and Lizzie- Mr.s Winston and Mrs. Wm. Jones &c Had we better send a Cofianl for Mrs. W.? J. & A. L.E.

Remsen, June 22, '83
Dear Sister 
While I wait for Anna 
to come to breakfast I will write 
a little to you.  This is a lovely 
bright day after a week almost 
[obscured] showers.  It is nice growing weather 
[obscured] the country is just beautiful.  
I am feeling better since coming
home tho' my arm pains me 
a little most all the time.  The 
medicine came all right.  Thank 
you for it.  I see that you had to 
buy it.  Let me know what it cost. 
Anna has come down and is ready 
for breakfast.  I will write a  
little, while Jennie is finishing 
her coffee.  We have enjoyed our 
visit with Phebe Michaels and

her mother very much.  They 
were disappointed in not seeing 
you as Mrs M is quite feeble 
and would like to have consulted 
you.  She has doctored some 
with Dr Sue White of Utica - 
do you know her?  She is a hom-
eopath.  We are very glad you 
are feeling better - but do not 
try to stay too long there [obscured] 
shall expect you here a part 
of the summer.  People tell 
me I look a great deal better 
than I did last summer - and 
think I must have found 
a good place.  I am feeling 
better, but keep tired all the  
time and so my back pains 
me a great deal.  Have been 
busy with my dolman - have 
it most finished - think it

is going to be very pretty.  The 
lettuce plants you sent all died 
most as soon as they were planted, 
though I shaded and watered them 
but they were too tender - you had 
not better send any more as ours 
are coming, and we have some we 
got from Mrs Edwards.  Tell Mrs T 
the fuchsia she gave me is doing 
[obscured] also some of the morning 
glory I took from her garden, and 
the little air plant.  Our friends 
here Mrs & Mr P are very kind and we enjoy 
being with them.  They make it 
seem as much like home to us as 
it is possible.  All the friends 
inquire for you, and will be 
glad to see you when you come. 
Have you seen the package of Adv. 
Cards which I did up and addressed 
to Carroll & Charlie - am afraid

they were packed with some 
books and pamphlets which 
have not been looked over - but 
you needn't trouble to look them 
up - I can share with the boys, and 
give them some of these.  Have 
you heard from Turin lately?  E. 
writes that Charlie has [obscured] 
getting along nicely.  How long Anna [obscured] 
in writing the above is no measure of the time 
I was "finishing" my coffee!  She let me wash 
the dishes &c and then she found George had 
gone and the chance for sending this 
by morning mail lost.  Mr & Mrs P are 
going this afternoon with their visitors to see Mrs Thos P Jones. 
George went to Glyn to take John Jones 
there together with some thigs for 
shingling.  He has just got back 
with the horse for thing to use this 
P.M.  The Michaels mean to leave tomorrow.

Home. Oct. 24, 1884.
Dear Sister, -Your good letter came yesterday, together with one from brother E., in which he said that he had just finished writing to you - he seems more cheery than sometimes, and they seem to be well provided for winter. Your letters do us a great deal of good - we are so glad you are happy and doing well. You must be careful not to overdo, and get sick - do not undertake too much. I would just like to be there to go with you to some of your classes. Does the private pupil you speak of pay you $50 or 50C for the 6 months tuition? we could hardly make out but judge by your saying in the

some connection that you are happy (underlined), that it must be the former. It is nice that you can meet your private pupils in the parlor of your boarding place. We had? a flurry of snow yesterday, so that the ground is white this morning and it is quite cold. Anna has just gone to eat - it is most time for George to start to the village so I shall have but a little time to talk - We think we had better have 2000 of the Arweinyd and not any of the Adyrgyd just now-

We had 3000 of the Catechism printed not very long ago and there are a good many of them on hand - Perhaps you had better get an estimate of what 2000 Arweinyd would be- We understand they are to be folded, covered and trimmed- Is that so? This is a bright day- We have been busy, canning pears, crabapples, pickling &c and are now making jelly-. Write often- Lovingly J.S & LE

Dear Sister
Your letter received Sat. eve. We do not think that it would be practicable for us to stop with you, tho' we thank you all the same. Sarah would not be able to go up and down stairs as you propose. She is weaker by far than you seem to think, and it looks doubtful to us about her being able to endure the fatigue of the journey unless she had a very quiet resting place afterwards. Do you still think Dunellen a favorable place for her. She was almost discouraged because you write that Mrs. Jones and Mrs. Thomas think it will be too cold there. Dr. was here yesterday and Sarah seemed quite bright and cheery then--he spoke encour

encouragingly. S. had taken some cold those frosty cold nights of last week and suffered with her side again but that was so much better that Dr. did not do anything for it. Last night was frosty again and she is worse again--coughs a good deal more. The sun is clear this morning and she is going for a ride. Dr. insists a great deal upon her getting out all she can. Sometimes we are greatly discouraged--the cold weather is coming so early and her strength is so small--there has been really no length of warm weather for her to gain in tho' we have had warm days--there have been almost as many cold. If everything could be arranged so that there would be no trouble in New York or at Dunnellen do you think it possible to have it so? How I wish you were not so confined by your business or that I could

go to see to have everything arranged. Perhaps Eddie will come home through N.Y. and do it for us. I think sometimes I will write to Tommy Thomas and see what he says about houses and rents. Remsen, Oct. 14, 1881
My dear Sister.
I believe Jennie wrote you last week that S. had taken some cold. It seemed to affect her head then--she had cold in the head, with diarrhea, but was better of that till Monday evening, when she had a slight chill, or chilly feeling, and could hardly keep her teeth from chattering. We got her warm very soon, and thought her no worse Tues. eve--she had similar chills at about the same time but not very severe. She has not felt as well since--has been quite feeble and suffered from great oppression in the chest and hoarseness. I can hardly tell whether this last is from the throat or tightness in the chest. She has had

a little sore throat now and then for several days. Uncle Henry and Hattie came here Wednesday, and staid all night, and we thought the trouble in her chest was partly (at least) from over exertion talking louder than usual with him. I went to see the Dr. yesterday, and told as well as I could how she was. He said he was afraid there was some pneumonia and told us to apply mustard to her chest. He will come to see her today, and after that I will write you again. I told him I hoped this would not prove very serious--he looked very sober and said, "Yes I hope so, but circumscribed pneumonia is not a pleasant thing to have in connection with tuberculosis." I think she is not any worse today than yesterday, but

is pretty feeble. The mustard relieved her some, but she was not able to keep it on long, as it made her so nervous. We have put on another this morning, as the skin was not reddened after last night. She had a little stitch in her left side last evening, which was relieved with mustard and aconite and Brg. This pains her some today still, but is a good deal better. We are very grateful to you for kindly offering to take us all in, if we should come to N.Y. but are afraid there would be no quiet resting place, with boarders and children, patients and all. I do not think she has been able yet to take the journey but cannot tell of course how it will be. Wish we could consult with you but of course our anxiety now is to have her relieved of this cold. We feel very anxious, but try to

hope for the best.

We have been having cold drizzly weather but today is clear after a hard frost last night we have not got the apples all in and a good many of them are injured by frost so that they can not be kept--we intend having cider made for vinegar from part. She and Anna had broiled oysters to supper Sat.--we all had some soup for Sunday breakfast and Sarah had raw oysters Sunday to supper. We had company to supper Sat. and Sunday; Mr. and Mrs. Wm. Prichard, Sat. the first time she had been out with her baby now five weeks old Sunday. Owen D. Griffith called and took tea with us. We baked the goose Sat. for dinner. Sarah said it was nice and seemed to relish it. This noon we had some of it cold and Sarah called for some of the bones to pick. After dinner she told 
number next year but he would not take anything. He said he meant to send us the Cen. as long as we would like to have it. It is very pleasant to have him feel so. Anna is going with J.E. to the village with this before supper.

We are having a very mild winter so far. There is scarcely a bit of snow to be seen any where. We shall have to cook our turkey pretty soon if the weather does not grow colder. We made a few sausages the last of the week--had some of them to dinner Sunday--all said they were good.
I am enclosing a letter we have just had from Hattie, that you may read it and answer her questions about oculists. Please return the letter because it is Sarah's. Did you read that last article in the last Cen. signed by Jane? What do you think of it? What do you suppose she means by asking to have all the "old debt" sent to her? Can you advise us what we had better have on the next Cen. cover. There should be something about the debt before [[1899?] and we would like
and as it is 4 p.m. I have not much more time to write. Much, much love from us four. Write often and do not wait for us. Your aff. sister J. Everett.

Turin,  March 29, 1882.
Dear Sister,
We are glad to get even a few words from you, but hope it will not be long before you can find time to write more fully. We are sorry that you are feeling so unsettled and we sympathize with you in your feeling of loneliness. Wish John Eddie might have gone to be with you but we did not feel like urging it much, against his judgement. He thought it would be wasting time for him to be going over the same ground as when he was there last, and we hope we have done right. We had a letter from him Saturday night. He had a comfortable, pleasant journey and reached Mexico about 3 p.m. Thursday and got nicely settled before night. He went through Syracuse as he did not

start early enough from Utica to reach Rome in season to get the Northern train for Mexico. He will perhaps write to you so I will not forestall.
Thursday P.M. I send this that you may see that I did try to write to you before, tho' there is not much in it. As it nears the last of the month we are wishing to know whether you have decided to move. I wish I might be with you to help for it--will be hard for you alone. How will it be if Mrs. Van Buren leaves and you stay. Must you be responsible for the rent of the whole flat? How is your health now? We shall be very glad to hear particularly--cards are good but they cannot quite take the place of letters. We have had two good full letters from John Eddie. He takes no studies now except Greek and Latin and writing. The classes are in advance of him but he hopes by application to keep up. They begin Virgil and Anabasis. His letter was written Monday, so he had not had much chance to tell. He attended Methodist church Sunday

morning with his roommate and in the evening went with Johnny to the Presbyterian church. 
The weather has been very variable this week. Sunday snowy, a soft wet snow which turned to rain. Anna and Mate? did not go out. E. and I went in the morning and the boys. They and their father went to Sunday school but I only went to the preaching service. Coming home Mrs. Hughes gave me the shelter of her umbrella as it was raining. Monday it rained hard all day--a warm rain from the south. The wind changed at night and Tuesday was exceeding cold with a sharp north wind. Anna and I went in the afternoon to the funeral of Mrs. Lyman's sister. Her body was brought from Forestville to be buried in the cemetery here by her husband. Services were at Mrs. L's. Yesterday was much warmer. We washed, and in the afternoon I went with Mrs. White to the Methodist church to the funeral of Mr. Hart's brother. Anna and Mate? went for a walk before tea and just before

going to bed I went up to the store for a walk. It was mild and pleasant but during the night there was quite a rainfall. Today there has been a strong cold wind with occasional flurries of fine snow. I went for a walk to the cemetery and back. The sidewalks are clear and dry, but the roads muddy.
I have just thought since beginning to write whether it would be much help for you if you move for me to go down a little while to help you. Anna would not miss me so much while she is here. My health is good and everybody remarks upon my looking so well. I was weighed last night--121 lbs. It is time for mail and I must close, but I must say we are having a great treat this maple sugar season.--have had some and made Jack wax and warm sugar several times. Adieu with love from all. Jennie Everett.

Remsen, Oct. 13, 1882
My dear Sister,
Your letter has not been followed by another fuller one according to promise. We fear you are not feeling well--wish very much we could have you with us. We have had quite a fright and all because we were too confiding and trustful in a stranger. Last Tuesday just as we were getting ready to sit down to tea a gentleman called and said his name was Everett and he thought perhaps he might find relatives here. We told him we thought he was mistaken. He said his father came from North Wales and 
Anna has much trouble with her head all the time. She finds it tires her a good deal to ride. Still it is better than staying home all this time. She enjoys going if she does get tired. She was most decided not to go to Utica--Mate? would want to come back the same day or the next and A. fears it would be too hard for her. Please write soon. Much love to you and other friends--Mrs. Jones, Thomas, Askin? &c. -J.E.

address--cousin Robert's, John's and I don't know but some others of our relatives. He said his aged mother was very anxious to know something of his father's relatives. His father had been dead many hears, We can see now that we were very green!
We are a little nervous nights and it does not seem pleasant to think of staying here so much alone. We do not know of any one who wants to rent and we do not fancy living here with another family. Would you care about trying to keep the place in the family? If you could be home awhile it seems that we could look over things and dispose of what we would not want to take to make a home elsewhere. We had a letter from John Eddie about the time we got yours. He asked how soon he had better come

cousin Robert's family and asked whether he was cousin Thomas' son. He said his father's name was Thomas--then I remembered I should have said cousin Robert. He replied that his brother's name was Robert. Well Anna came and talked with him and I invited him to supper with us, and afterwards as it grew late we invited to stay all night. We had no where to put him but in ma's bed room. I remembered that my purse with $13 was in the drawer and I put it in my packed and took it up stairs thinking of the petition "lead us not into temptation." I thought Anna's was up stairs but I did not ask her. We did not get up very early the next morning and he did not come from the room till we were just ready for breakfast at eight. He said he was going to Western to find his mother's

relatives. He had been to the Adriandae's? for his health &c. &c. After he left us Mate was going with Robbie to the village. Anna went to her purse to get some money to send for something. There should have been unclear and a little change there. He had taken all but a few cents change--also some from the drawer of the missionary collection. We do not know exactly how much. It was the Feb. col? and we had never opened it. He left 38 its probably took .50 or .75. We do not know whether he took anything else. The box with papers was in that large trunk in the recess--we think he did not look there but my fur gloves which I kept in the lower drawer we found under the wash stand. The week before there were some burglaries committed in the village. We did not know what to do and so did nothing about following him. Anna gave him Aunt Hughe?

What do you suppose it would cost?
Our garden has been doing very well--our potatoes hold out well and are excellent. The boys hoed them before their father started and they have hoed more or less in the garden since. The celery looks nicely--they have hoed that twice with Anna's help.
Thomas Evans was hurt badly the other day. The horse ran away with and threw him out breaking some of his ribs and cutting his head. We drove into Fremont's yard to enquire. Lydia was with her father. F. could not tell--I suppose they did not know just what his injuries are.
We are well--are going to the village this morning and so must hasten to close.

Glyn 11 a.m. Nov. 9, 1882
Dear Sister,
A. rested well last night and thinks she feels stronger today than she has at all since that Wednesday. We got your letter yesterday and were very glad. Jane was here last evening--also R. & L. This is a mild and very pleasant day. Mr. & Mrs. P. wish to be remembered to you. Cousin  Evan and family were here this p.m. They will not probably take this place as it is not so large as they want. A. enjoyed the visit with them. She came to table both to dinner & tea. She is now in the sitting room. Mr. & Mrs. Wm Thomas are there. I am finishing this to send with them. We
have not had the mail today.

Remsen,  March 29, 1898
My dear Sister,
